entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 26 at 4:35AM PST until February 27 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of up to 11 inches with localized amounts up to 15 inches. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...The Sierra Nevada above 6,000 feet, mainly Yosemite National Park to Sequoia National Park.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 26 at 6:35AM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
Latest surface observations indicate localized dense fog has formed in the vicinity of the city of Zapata. Visibility has been reduced to less than one-quarter mile. The dense fog is expected to persist through mid-morning, motorists are urged to utilize extra time to reach your destinations this morning.
Motorists should use low beam headlights, reduce speed, and leave extra space when encountering fog.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Zapata

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued February 26 at 5:25AM MST until February 26 at 6:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM TO 6 PM TODAY FOR THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS AND EASTERN PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FOR LATE TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY EVENING FOR THE EASTERN PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY...
.Critical to near-critical fire weather conditions are expected today across the northeastern highlands and eastern plains of New Mexico as strong to very strong winds develop. Gusts will range from 35 to 60 mph. While relative humidity will be generally between 15 and 20 percent, strong winds will be capable of carrying fire in dry grasses and fuels.
Winds will be even stronger on Tuesday with more widespread gusts of 55 to 65 mph. Relative humidity will again be somewhat marginal in a 15 to 20 percent range, but fine fuels will remain dry and vulnerable.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Tuesday morning through Tuesday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Plains (Zone 104) and East Central Plains (Zone 126) from 11 AM to 6 PM MST today and from late morning Tuesday through the early evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...Sustained out of the west at 25 to 40 mph with occasional gusts up 35 to 60 mph today. Winds will strengthen more on Tuesday with sustained speeds out of the west at 35 to 45 mph and occasional gusts of 55 to 65 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values of 15 to 20 percent each day.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 6 PM MST THIS EVENING... ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 26 at 5:14AM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
AVWMSO
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Missoula Avalanche Center Missoula MT
...The Missoula Avalanche Center Missoula MT has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING...
* WHAT...Avalanche danger will rise to high late Sunday night and continue through Monday for a strong winter storm impacting the area with significant snowfall and high winds.
* WHERE...On and below steep slopes at middle and upper elevations in the southern Swan range, southern Missions, Rattlesnake mountains, and the Bitterroot mountains from Lolo Pass to Lost Trail Pass.
* WHEN...In effect from Sunday, February 25, 2024 8:00 PM MST to Monday, February 26, 2024 8:00 PM MST.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow combined with wind has created widespread areas of unstable snow.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Missoula, MT; Ravalli, MT

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 26 at 5:09AM MST by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
AVWBYZ
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center.
The Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center is issuing a Backcountry Avalanche Warning for the mountains around Cooke City, where 10 inches of snow fell in the last 24 hours, and an additional 7-10 inches is forecast for today. Strong southwest winds are blowing snow and exacerbating the instability. The snowpack is unstable, and triggering avalanches is very likely. Avoid avalanche terrain and avalanche runout zones. Very dangerous avalanche conditions exist. The avalanche danger is HIGH on all slopes. Contact the Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center for more detailed information.
Website: www.mtavalanche.com Avalanche Hotline: 406-587-6981
This warning will expire or be updated by 6:00 a.m. on Tuesday, February 27th.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Absaroka/Beartooth Mountains

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 26 at 6:45AM EST by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
A line of robust snow showers and potential snow squalls are expected to reach the North Woods and Moosehead Region between Noon and 2PM. The line will reach I-95 between 2PM and 4PM and push east into New Brunswick by 6PM. Snow showers and squalls may produce rapidly changing conditions resulting in slippery travel.
Be prepared for whiteouts with near zero visibility...creating extremely dangerous driving conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 26 at 5:17AM CST by NWS Mobile AL
entry.summary: Current observations, reports, and satellite data suggest patchy dense fog has formed across portions of Stone and George Counties. This in combination with wildfire smoke across the area has resulted in a few spots seeing reduced visibility to near a quarter of a mile. The fog appears to be too patchy to warrant a dense fog advisory at this time; however, caution should be utilized this morning while travelling if encountering patches of dense fog. Fog should begin to mix out shortly after sunrise.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Stone; George

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 26 at 4:45AM CST by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
Warm temperatures, gusty south winds, low relative humidity, and dry vegetation will create conditions favorable for the rapid spread and growth of fire this afternoon.
Outdoor burning is discouraged. If cooking outdoors, keep a careful watch on the grill. Burning embers can blow around and easily catch grass on fire. Improperly discared cigarettes can also start fires which will spread quickly.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 26 at 12:44AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
If you thought old-man winter was over because of the recent warm temps, you were wrong. Another arctic blast is upcoming for the Northern Mainland. This is not necessarily unusual, but it will still be anomalous, as low temps plummet back to the -30 F range (the coldest valley locations will fall into the -40 F range).
Temperatures fall well below normal Tuesday night, but the bottom doesn't fall out until Wednesday night, with the coldest temps likely occurring Thursday night and Friday night. It will remain quite cold through most of the weekend although temps will slowly be climbing back out of the deep-freeze, slowly.
This cold-snap will not reach the same extremes as the last one at the end of January and early February, but it will still be anomalous for this time of year. The one big difference will be daytime highs will be much warmer than a month ago, since we now see quite a bit more solar radiation and daytime warming.
Don't put that Interior winter-gear away quite yet!
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes Of The Eastern Brooks Range; South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Dalton Highway Summits; Yukon Flats; White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River; Fortymile Country; Upper Tanana Valley; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: Another Arctic Blast Upcoming Late This Week and Weekend

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued February 26 at 3:35AM CST until February 26 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
...Extreme Fire Weather Conditions Today...
.Record-breaking warmth will combine with winds out of the southwest gusting to 30-35 mph at times, antecedent dry conditions, and relative humidity dropping under 25 percent through much of central Iowa. This will result in extreme fire weather conditions across much of the state.
* AFFECTED AREA...All of Central Iowa
* WIND...Out of the southwest at 15-25 mph, gusting to 30-35 mph.
* HUMIDITY...15 to 25 percent during the afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. A few counties in central to western Iowa already have burn bans in effect.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued February 26 at 3:29AM CST until February 27 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions possible. Total snow accumulations of up to two inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Griggs and Barnes Counties.
* WHEN...From late Monday night through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Very difficult or impossible travel conditions may develop. Widespread blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions are likely to impact the morning commute. Cold wind chills as low as 20 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...For blizzard conditions to occur, either higher rates of falling snow or enough new snow on the ground will need to occur at the time stronger winds develop. There is currently a 60 percent chance for blizzard conditions over parts of the Red River Valley and eastern North Dakota.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Griggs; Barnes

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 26 at 3:26AM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
Light ice accumulations of around 0.01" may lead to slippery roads. Snowfall totals up to an inch are expected. If you plan on traveling early this morning before 8 AM, allow extra time to reach your destination. Don't use cruise control. Be especially careful around stop lights, school bus stops, and intersections.
Check road conditions... By Phone: call 511 Website for North Dakota: travel.dot.nd.gov Website for Minnesota: 511mn.org

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued February 26 at 2:50AM CST until February 26 at 6:00PM CST by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
...Critical Fire Weather Conditions for Northeast Iowa Today...
.An airmass more reminiscent of early spring rather than winter will make for critical fire weather conditions across northeast Iowa today.
Record to near record heat with high temperatures in the upper 60s to around 70, humidities dropping to around 20 percent, and southerly wind gusts pushing into the lower 30s mph will allow for quick starting, fast moving fires.
Any outdoor burning could quickly get out of hand and should be avoided today.
* AFFECTED AREA...In Iowa, Mitchell, Howard, Winneshiek, Allamakee, Floyd, Chickasaw, Fayette and Clayton.
* TIMING...this morning through the afternoon.
* WINDS...South 15 to 25 mph with gusts from 30 to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 20 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 70.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that start could spread rapidly and become hard to control. Please heed any local burning bans.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mitchell; Howard; Winneshiek; Allamakee; Floyd; Chickasaw; Fayette; Clayton

entry.summary:

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 25 at 7:54PM EST until February 27 at 5:48AM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Everett City affecting McIntosh, Glynn and Wayne Counties.
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Long and Wayne Counties.
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Tattnall, Toombs, Appling and Wayne Counties.
Satilla River At Atkinson affecting Brantley County.
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Montgomery, Toombs and Jeff Davis Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Monday evening at 700 PM EST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Charlotteville.
* WHEN...Until early Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Bankfull conditions occur along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Some flooding begins in low lying areas around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage in south Montgomery County. The water will approach portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 13.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding occurs in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water reaches the top of the public boat ramp by the bridge. Flood waters expand in low lying areas in south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will begin to cover portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 14.0 feet, Minor flooding continues in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water covers the low portion and entrance of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. The public boat ramp is under two feet of water. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. Flood waters continue to expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 2 to 4 feet over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:45 PM EST Sunday the stage was 15.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late tomorrow evening and continue falling to 8.8 feet Friday evening. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 25 at 7:54PM EST until March 1 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Everett City affecting McIntosh, Glynn and Wayne Counties.
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Long and Wayne Counties.
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Tattnall, Toombs, Appling and Wayne Counties.
Satilla River At Atkinson affecting Brantley County.
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Montgomery, Toombs and Jeff Davis Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Monday evening at 700 PM EST.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Everett City.
* WHEN...Until early Friday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Agricultural and timber lands near the river are flooded. At 13.0 feet, Water begins to encroach upon Altamaha Regional Park in Glynn County. This includes Altamaha Park Road, Betty Lott Lane and Bee Tree Island Road. In McIntosh County, Barrington Park at the end of Harper Lake Road begins to flood. Blue Reach Road also begins to flood near the Long County line. At 14.0 feet, Portions of Altamaha Regional Park become inundated, including the park campground, boat ramps and parking lots. Bee Tree Island Road is flooded and closed. The end of Betty Lott Lane is flooded and homes become cut off. At 15.0 feet, In Glynn County, the majority of Altamaha Regional Park becomes inundated, including water flowing across sections of Altamaha Park Road and Pennick Road. The Altamaha Regional Park is subject to closure at this level. Homes in the vicinity of the park are cut off by flood waters at this level, but elevated structures are not flooded. In McIntosh County, much of Barrington Park is underwater. Plum Orchard Road begins to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 PM EST Sunday the stage was 14.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 14.5 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage Friday morning. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 25 at 5:24PM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
AVWMSO
The following message is transmitted at the request of Flathead Avalanche Center Hungry Horse MT.
...AVALANCHE WARNING ISSUED BY THE FLATHEAD AVALANCHE CENTER...
18:00 MST Sun Feb 25 2024 The Flathead Avalanche Center in Hungry Horse has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING for the following areas:
NWS Missoula MT - MTC 029 (Flathead County)
* WHAT...The avalanche danger will rise Sunday night and Monday as a powerful storm sweeps across the forecast region. If the storm develops as forecast, the likelihood and size of triggered and natural avalanches will increase.
* WHERE...On and below steep slopes at middle and upper elevations in the Flathead Range and parts of Glacier National Park (John F. Stevens Canyon and Marias Pass area).
* WHEN...In effect from Sun 18:00 MST to Mon 18:00 MST.
* IMPACTS...Forecasted heavy snow combined with strong winds will likely create widespread areas of unstable snow.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected to develop. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended. Avalanches may run long distances and can run into mature forests, valley floors, or flat terrain.
Consult http://www.flatheadavalanche.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Flathead, MT

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 25 at 4:21PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVABOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 5PM SUNDAY UNTIL 6AM WEDNESDAY...
* WHAT...Dangerous avalanche conditions are developing. Expect the Avalanche Danger to rise to HIGH (Level 4 of 5) Monday night.
* WHERE...Park Range, Gore Range, Elk Mountains, Ruby Range, West Elk Mountains, and Sawatch Range.
* WHEN...Expect dangerous avalanche conditions to begin on Monday night and last through Wednesday at 6:00 AM.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow and strong winds will create dangerous avalanche conditions by Monday night. Avalanches will break wide across terrain features and run long distances. Avalanches will run naturally.
* PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Travel in, near, or under avalanche terrain is not recommended Tuesday or Wednesday. Avoid travel on and under slopes steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 25 at 12:27PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary: A strong low currently in the Bering Sea will move east through Monday. Snow from the associated front will begin to accumulate in earnest beginning late Monday night with impactful snowfall lasting through late Tuesday night. Any given 12-hour period may see accumulations of 3 to 6 inches during this event, which is enough to adversely impact vehicular travel and may also affect marine & aviation activities. With day time highs and overnight lows well below normal, initial snow ratios will likely be quite high, meaning "light and fluffy". At present, no significant post- frontal warm up is expected, so snow ratios may remain high throughout the event, making for easier snow removal.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: MORE ACCUMULATING SNOW POSSIBLE TUESDAY INTO TUESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 25 at 2:14PM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
Light ice accumulations of greater than 0.01" may lead to slippery roads. Snowfall totals up to an inch are expected. If you plan on traveling between midnight and 8 AM, allow extra time to reach your destination. Don't use cruise control. Be especially careful around stop lights, school bus stops, and intersections.
Check road conditions... By Phone: call 511 Website for North Dakota: travel.dot.nd.gov Website for Minnesota: 511mn.org

entry.summary:
AVAMSO
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Missoula Avalanche Center Missoula MT
...The Missoula Avalanche Center Missoula MT has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH...
* WHAT...Avalanche danger will rise today as a strong winter storm impacts the area. Avalanche danger could reach high by early Monday morning.
* WHERE...On and below steep slopes at middle and upper elevations in the southern Swan range, southern Missions, Rattlesnake mountains, and the Bitterroot mountains from Lolo Pass to Lost Trail Pass.
* WHEN...In effect from Sunday, February 25, 2024 615 AM MST to Monday, February 26, 2024 615 AM MST.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow and strong winds will create dangerous avalanche conditions and widespread areas of unstable snow.

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 24 at 6:34PM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
AVAMSO
The following message is transmitted at the request of Flathead Avalanche Center Hungry Horse MT.
...AVALANCHE WATCH ISSUED BY THE FLATHEAD AVALANCHE CENTER...
18:00 MST Sat Feb 24 2024 The Flathead Avalanche Center in Hungry Horse has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH for the following areas:
NWS Missoula MT - MTC 029 (Flathead County)...MTC 047 (Lake County)...MTC 053 (Lincoln County)
* WHAT...The avalanche danger will rise Sunday and Sunday night as a powerful storm sweeps across the forecast region. If the storm develops as forecast, the likelihood and size of triggered and natural avalanches will increase.
* WHERE...On and below steep slopes at middle and upper elevations in the Whitefish Range, Swan Range, Flathead Range, and parts of Glacier National Park (Apgar Range, John F. Stevens Canyon, and Marias Pass area).
* WHEN...In effect from Sat 18:00 MST to Sun 18:00 MST.
* IMPACTS...Forecasted heavy snow combined with strong winds will likely create widespread areas of unstable snow.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected to develop. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended. Avalanches may run long distances and can run into mature forests, valley floors, or flat terrain.
Consult http://www.flatheadavalanche.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Flathead, MT; Lake, MT; Lincoln, MT
